text.headline: Empires of the Silk Roads
text.text:
A summary of the Empires, Caliphates and Dynasties of the Silk Roads between 500 B.C. and 1500 A.D.

Developed as an aide-memoire for the Peter Frankopan book, 'The Silk Roads - A New History of the World' and the 2024 British Museum Silk Roads Exhibition the latter of which focused on the period of 500-1000 AD

Content largely derived from Wikipedia & Wikimedia Commons.

Timeline created using Knightlab's Timeline software

text.headline: The Achaemenid or First Persian Empire
text.text:
The first Persian Empire, founded by Cyrus the Great in the 6th century BCE, and became one of the largest empires in history, stretching from the Indus Valley to Thrace and Egypt.

Under rulers like Cyrus the Great and Darius I, the empire expanded through military conquests, incorporating a vast range of cultures and peoples while promoting a policy of tolerance and governance through local satraps (governors).

The Achaemenids are renowned for their achievements in infrastructure, such as the construction of the Royal Road, and their advancements in administration, including the use of a standardized currency and efficient taxation systems.

The empire fell in 330 BCE after the conquest of Persia by Alexander the Great, marking the end of Achaemenid rule and the beginning of Hellenistic influence in the region.

media.credit: By Unknown author - This file has been extracted from another file, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=66715266

text.headline: The Macedonian Empire - Alexander the Great
text.text:
In 334 BC, Alexander invaded the Achaemenid Persian Empire and began a series of campaigns that lasted for 10 years. Following his conquest of Asia Minor, he broke the power of Achaemenid Persia in a series of decisive battles, including those at Issus and Gaugamela; he subsequently overthrew Darius III and conquered the Achaemenid Empire in its entirety.

After the fall of Persia, the Macedonian Empire held a vast swath of territory between the Adriatic Sea and the Indus River. Alexander endeavored to reach the "ends of the world and the Great Outer Sea" and invaded India in 326 BC, achieving an important victory over Porus, an ancient Indian king of present-day Punjab, at the Battle of the Hydaspes

Due to the mutiny of his homesick troops, he eventually turned back at the Beas River and later died in 323 BC in Babylon, the city of Mesopotamia that he had planned to establish as his empire's capital.

text.headline: The Seleucid Empire
text.text:
The Seleucid Empire was a Greek state in West Asia during the Hellenistic period. It was founded in 312 BC by the Macedonian general Seleucus I Nicator, following the division of the Macedonian Empire founded by Alexander the Great, and ruled by the Seleucid dynasty until its annexation by the Roman Republic under Pompey in 63 BC.

The Seleucid-Parthian Wars were a series of conflicts between the Seleucid Empire and the Parthian Empire which resulted in the ultimate expulsion of the Seleucids from the Iranian Plateau and the surrounding regions. The wars were caused by the mass migration of the nomadic Iranian Parni tribe into Parthia and the establishment of the Parthian state, which challenged Seleucid hegemony.

text.headline: The Parthian or Arsacid Empire
text.text:
The Parthian Empire, also known as the Arsacid Empire, was a major Iranian political and cultural power centered in ancient Iran. Its latter name comes from its founder, Arsaces I, who led the Parni tribe in conquering the region of Parthia in Iran's northeast, then a satrapy (province) under Andragoras, who was rebelling against the Seleucid Empire.

Mithridates I (171-132 BC) greatly expanded the empire by seizing Media and Mesopotamia from the Seleucids. At its height, the Parthian Empire stretched from the northern reaches of the Euphrates, in what is now central-eastern Turkey, to present-day Afghanistan and western Pakistan. The empire, located on the Silk Road trade route between the Roman Empire in the Mediterranean Basin and the Han dynasty of China, became a center of trade and commerce.

text.headline: The Han Dynasty
text.text:
An imperial dynasty of China established by Liu Bang and ruled by the House of Liu. The dynasty was preceded by the short-lived Qin dynasty and a warring interregnum known as the Chu-Han Contention, and it was succeeded by the Three Kingdoms period.

Spanning over four centuries, the Han dynasty is considered a golden age in Chinese history, and had a permanent impact on Chinese identity in later periods

text.headline: The Roman Empire under Trajan
text.text: A philanthropic ruler and a successful soldier-emperor who presided over one of the greatest military expansions in Roman history, during which, by the time of his death, the Roman Empire reached its maximum territorial extent.

text.headline: The Kushan Empire
text.text: A syncretic empire formed by the Yuezhi in the Bactrian territories in the early 1st century. It spread to encompass much of what is now Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Eastern Iran and Northern India, at least as far as Saketa and Sarnath, near Varanasi, where inscriptions have been found dating to the era of the Kushan emperor Kanishka the Great.

text.headline: The Sasanian Empire
text.text:
• The last empire of ancient Iran, named after the House of Sasan, and succeeded the Parthian Arsacid dynasty.
  • It fell to the Rashidun Caliphate in the 7th century, leading to the Islamization of Iran.
  • Founded by Ardashir I after defeating the Parthians, the Sasanian dynasty sought to restore the Achaemenid Empire's legacy and frequently clashed with the Roman Empire.
  • At its peak, the empire covered modern-day Iran, Iraq, parts of the Arabian Peninsula, the Caucasus, the Levant, Central Asia, and South Asia.

text.headline: The Byzantine or Eastern Roman Empire
text.text: A continuation of the Roman Empire centred in Constantinople during late antiquity and the Middle Ages. Surviving the conditions that led to the fall of the Western Roman Empire in the 5th century AD, it endured until the fall of Constantinople to the Ottoman Empire in 1453. For much of its history, the empire remained the most powerful economic, cultural, and military force in the Mediterranean world. The term 'Byzantine Empire' was coined only after its demise; its citizens called the polity the 'Roman Empire' and themselves 'Romans'

media.caption: Turkish miniature paintings depicting Muhammad and the first four Caliphs of Islam
media.credit: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Rashidun Caliphate
text.text: Consisted of the first four successive caliphs (lit.?'successors') - Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, and Ali, collectively known as the Rashidun, or "Rightly Guided" caliphs who led the Muslim community and polity from the death of the Islamic prophet Muhammad (in 632 CE), to the establishment of the Umayyad Caliphate.

media.caption: The Great Mosque or Umayyad Mosque in Damascus was constructed on the orders of Abd al-Malik, begun c.?705 and completed shortly after his death in 715.
media.credit: © Vyacheslav Argenberg / http://www.vascoplanet.com/, CC BY 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Umayyad Caliphate
text.text:
The first hereditary dynasty of the Islamic Caliphate, ruling from 661 to 750 and spanning territories from Spain to India.

Founded by Mu'awiya I after the first Fitna (656661), the Umayyads established their capital in Damascus, marking the shift from a community-led caliphate to a dynastic empire.

The Umayyads are known for their military expansion, which brought vast regions of North Africa, the Iberian Peninsula, and Central Asia under Islamic rule, as well as for fostering Arabic as the language of administration and culture.

The dynasty was overthrown by the Abbasid revolution in 750, though a branch of the Umayyads survived in Spain, establishing the Caliphate of Córdoba, which continued until 1031.

media.caption: Uyghur princes wearing Chinese-styled robes and headgear. Bezeklik, Cave 9
media.credit: 9th-12th century Uyghur artist, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Uyghur Khaganate
text.text:
A Central Asian empire that existed from 744 to 840 AD, founded by the Uighur people after they overthrew the previous Turkic Khaganate.

The Khaganate's capital was initially at Ordu-Baliq, which became a major center of trade and culture.

The Uighur Khaganate played a significant role in the political dynamics of the region, allying with the Tang Dynasty of China and influencing the Silk Road trade.

The empire ultimately fell in 840 AD due to internal rebellions and invasions by the Kirghiz, marking the end of Uighur dominance in Central Asia.

media.caption: Baghdad 150 to 300
media.credit: William Muir, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Abbasid Caliphate
text.text:
Succeeded the Umayyads and shifted the capital to Baghdad, fostering a golden age of Islamic culture and scholarship.

It was known for its advancements in science, medicine, mathematics, and literature, with institutions like the House of Wisdom playing a key role in knowledge preservation and translation.

The empire's administration was highly bureaucratic, incorporating Persian influences and a complex taxation system to govern its vast territories efficiently.

The Abbasid Caliphate declined due to internal strife, economic difficulties, and Mongol invasions, culminating in the sack of Baghdad in 1258.

media.caption: Khazar fortress at Sarkel (Belaya Vyezha, Russia)
media.credit: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Khazar Khaganate
text.text:
A powerful Turkic state that controlled trade routes between Europe and Asia, acting as a buffer between the Islamic Caliphates and the Byzantine Empire.

The Khazars adopted Judaism as the state religion in the 8th or 9th century, making them unique among Turkic and steppe peoples.

The Khaganate maintained a strong military and diplomatic presence, forming alliances with Byzantium and resisting Arab expansion into Eastern Europe.

The Khazar state declined due to attacks from the Rus' and internal strife, eventually falling to the Kievan Rus in the late 10th century.

media.caption: Silk with depiction of horsemen, produced under the Buyids
media.credit: Alborz Fallah, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Buyid Dynasty
text.text:
A Persian Shia dynasty that ruled over parts of Iran and Iraq from the 10th to the 11th century, establishing a strong military and administrative presence.

Founded by the three Buyid brothers, Ali, Hasan, and Ahmad, the dynasty gained power by taking control of Baghdad in 945, effectively making the Abbasid caliphs their puppet rulers.

Despite their political dominance, the Buyids adopted a policy of religious tolerance, allowing Sunni and Shia Muslims to coexist while promoting Persian culture and administration.

The dynasty eventually declined due to internal conflicts and external pressures, culminating in their conquest by the Seljuk Turks in 1055, marking the end of their rule.

background.credit: Ro4444 at English Wikipedia, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

media.caption: Radzivill chronicle. List 10
media.credit: Site about Radzivill chronicle: [1], Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Kievan Rus'
text.text:
A medieval state that emerged in the 9th century, uniting various Slavic and Finnic tribes under the rule of the Varangians, with its capital in Kyiv.

Founded by the Rurikid dynasty, it reached its peak under rulers like Vladimir the Great and Yaroslav the Wise, who expanded its territory and established Christianity as the state religion in 988.

Kievan Rus became a major trade and cultural center, linking Scandinavia, Byzantium, and the Islamic world while fostering early Slavic literacy and legal codes.

The state declined due to internal fragmentation and external invasions, culminating in the Mongol conquest in the 13th century, which led to its disintegration.

media.caption: Simeon I of Bulgaria sending envoys to the Fatimid Caliph Ubayd Allah al-Mahdi.
media.credit: John Skylitzes, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Fatimid Caliphate
text.text:
An Ismaili Shia dynasty that ruled over large parts of North Africa, the Levant, and the Arabian Peninsula from 909 to 1171, with its capital eventually established in Cairo.

Founded by Abdullah al-Mahdi Billah, the dynasty claimed descent from Fatimah, the daughter of Prophet Muhammad, and sought to challenge the Sunni Abbasid Caliphate.

The Fatimids were known for their prosperous economy, advancements in science and culture, and the establishment of Cairo as a major intellectual and religious center, including the founding of Al-Azhar University.

The caliphate declined due to internal strife, military defeats, and the rise of the Sunni Ayyubid dynasty under Salah ad-Din, who abolished Fatimid rule in 1171.

media.caption: Mahmud of Ghazni receiving a richly decorated robe of honor from the caliph al-Qadir in 1000.
media.credit: Rashid-al-Din Hamadani, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Ghaznavids
text.text:
A Persianate Muslim empire, originating in Ghazni (modern-day Afghanistan) and expanding into Persia, Central Asia, and the Indian subcontinent.

Founded by Alp Tigin and later consolidated by his successor, Mahmud of Ghazni, the dynasty became known for its military conquests, including multiple invasions of northern India, which spread Islam and Persian culture.

The Ghaznavids were great patrons of Persian literature, art, and architecture, with figures like Ferdowsi, the author of the Shahnameh, flourishing under their rule.

The dynasty eventually declined due to Seljuk invasions and internal strife, leading to their defeat by the Ghurids in the late 12th century, marking the end of their rule.

text.headline: The Kara-Khanid Khanate
text.text:
A Turkic dynasty that ruled Central Asia from the 10th to the 13th century, controlling territories in modern-day Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, and parts of China.

Originating from the Karluk Turks, the Kara-Khanids played a crucial role in the Islamization of Central Asia, with their ruler Sultan Satuq Bughra Khan converting to Islam in the 10th century.

Their rule saw the development of Persianate culture, the flourishing of cities like Kashgar and Samarkand, and the blending of Turkic and Islamic traditions in art and governance.

The dynasty weakened due to internal divisions and external pressures, ultimately falling under the control of the Western Liao and later being absorbed by the Khwarazmian Empire in the early 13th century.

media.caption: The Seljuk Sultan Barkiaruq( r.10931104), the son of Malikshah (r. 10721092), from a Manuscript of Hafiz-i Abrus Majma al-tawarikh
media.credit: Yale University Art Gallery, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Seljuk Empire
text.text:
A Sunni Muslim Turkish dynasty that ruled vast territories across Persia, Anatolia, and the Levant from the 11th to the 13th century, playing a key role in Islamic and Middle Eastern history.

Founded by Tughril Beg in the mid-11th century, the Seljuks defeated the Ghaznavids and took control of Baghdad in 1055, becoming protectors of the Abbasid Caliphate.

Under rulers like Alp Arslan and Malik Shah, the empire expanded significantly, introduced Persian as the administrative language, and saw cultural advancements, including the patronage of scholars like Omar Khayyam and Al-Ghazali.

The empire eventually fragmented due to internal strife and external invasions, with the Mongols conquering the last remnants of Seljuk rule in the 13th century.

media.caption: Coronation of Il-Arslan. This painting is from the book Jami' al-Tawarikh (literally "Compendium of Chronicles" but often referred to as The Universal History or History of the World), by Rashid al-Din, published in Tabriz, Persia, 1307 A.D.
media.credit: Rashid Al-Din, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Khwarazmian Empire
text.text:
A Persianate Sunni Muslim dynasty that ruled parts of Central Asia, Iran, and Afghanistan, emerging from the region of Khwarazm.

Originally vassals of the Seljuks, the Khwarazmian rulers gained independence under Ala al-Din Tekish and expanded their empire significantly under his son, Ala al-Din Muhammad.

The empire flourished as a center of trade and culture, but conflicts with the Abbasids and neighboring powers weakened its stability, making it vulnerable to external threats.

The Khwarazmian Empire met its downfall when it was brutally destroyed by the Mongol invasion led by Genghis Khan in the 1220s, marking the end of Khwarazmian rule.

media.caption: Taizu, better known as Genghis Khan

text.headline: The Mongol Empire
text.text:
The largest contiguous land empire in history, founded by Genghis Khan in 1206 and expanding across Asia, the Middle East, and Eastern Europe.

Known for their military prowess, the Mongols used superior cavalry tactics, psychological warfare, and an efficient communication system to conquer vast territories, including the Khwarazmian Empire, China, and Persia.

Despite their reputation for brutality in warfare, the Mongols promoted trade, cultural exchange, and religious tolerance, facilitating the growth of the Silk Road and connecting different civilizations.

The empire eventually fractured into four major khanates-the Yuan Dynasty, the Ilkhanate, the Chagatai Khanate, and the Golden Horde, leading to its gradual decline by the late 14th century.

media.caption: The fall of Tripoli to the Mamluks, April 1289. This was a battle towards the end of the Crusades, in what is modern-day Lebanon.

text.headline: The Mamluk Sultanate
text.text:
A powerful medieval Muslim state that ruled Egypt and the Levant, initially established by Mamluks, slave soldiers who rose to political power.

Originating as military slaves under the Ayyubid dynasty, the Mamluks seized control of Egypt in 1250, defeating the Ayyubids, and established their own sultanate, with Cairo as their capital.

Known for their military strength and defense of the Islamic world, the Mamluks successfully repelled the Mongol invasions and fought off the Crusaders, ensuring the survival of the Islamic Caliphate in the region.

The Mamluk Sultanate declined due to internal conflicts, weakening military power, and the rise of the Ottoman Empire, which eventually conquered Egypt in 1517, ending the Mamluk rule.

media.caption: Timur
media.credit: user:shakko, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Timurid Empire
text.text:
A Central Asian empire founded by Timur (Tamerlane) in the late 14th century, spanning modern-day Iran, Central Asia, parts of India, and the Middle East.

Timur, a descendant of Genghis Khan, established his empire through military conquest, becoming renowned for his brutal campaigns and the creation of a vast, diverse empire centered in Samarkand.

The empire is notable for its cultural achievements, with the Timurid rulers being great patrons of Persian art, architecture, and the sciences, leading to the flourishing of cities like Herat and Samarkand.

After Timur's death in 1405, the empire fragmented into smaller states, and despite efforts to maintain unity, the Timurid legacy eventually declined, largely due to internal strife and the rise of competing powers in the region.
